content.description:
Read the following poem carefully before you choose your answers.

Effie Waller Smith’s poem “The Recompense” was published in 1909.

The Recompense1reward
 O ancient ocean, with what courage stern
 Thy tides, since time began, have sought to gain
 The luring moon, toward which they rise in vain,
 Yet daily to their futile aim return.
5Like thee do glorious human spirits yearn
 And strive and fail and strive and fail again
 Some starlike aspiration to attain,
 Some light that ever shall above them burn.

Yet truly shall their recompense abide
10To all who strive, although unreached their goal:
 The ceaseless surgings of the ocean tide
 Do cleanse the mighty waters which they roll,
 And the high dreams in which it vainly sighed
 Make pure the deeps of the aspiring soul.
content.question: The rhyming words in lines 2 and 3 (“gain” and “vain”) primarily serve to suggest

choices.label: a contrast between hope and reality
the elusiveness of an abstract concept
a shift from the literal to the metaphorical

content.answer: a contrast between hope and reality

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Explain the function of structure in a text.
